sub_topic: Calculating the bond dissociation energy of a molecule
message_1: What is the bond dissociation energy (in kJ/mol) of the H-H bond in H2 molecule if it requires 436 kJ/mol of energy to break one mole of H2 into individual H atoms?
message_2:
The bond dissociation energy is the energy required to break a bond in a molecule. In this case, we are given that it requires 436 kJ/mol of energy to break one mole of H2 into individual H atoms. Since there is only one H-H bond in an H2 molecule, the bond dissociation energy of the H-H bond is equal to the energy required to break one mole of H2.

Therefore, the bond dissociation energy of the H-H bond in H2 molecule is 436 kJ/mol.
